div.p: Issaquah School District held its first Virtual Spirit Week March 30 - April 3 on Facebook. Thank you to all the parents, students and staff who submitted pictures and videos to make the week a success!
See the submissions on the ISD Facebook page. Here's a video recap of the week:

div.div: ISD Donates Protective Equipment to Healthcare Staff

div.p: The District recently heard from Swedish Hospital in Issaquah and Providence Marianwood asking for donations of any available protective equipment, including masks, gowns, gloves, and goggles. These items are crucial to protect healthcare workers who care for patients suffering from COVID-19, and supplies are running low.

ISD staff members gathered supplies from schools across the district that would have been used for student health and science classes, as well as supplies from school health rooms. On March 25, staff members from Swedish and Providence picked up the donations and took them to their care facilities to be put to use by the people on the front lines of dealing with the pandemic.
Thank you to all healthcare workers!

img.alt: ISD Donates Protective Equipment to Healthcare Staff

div.div: Video Message from Superintendent about School Closures

Issaquah School District Superintendent Ron Thiele speaks about what the District has done and is doing during the extended school closure due to COVID-19.
For info about supports available, visit www.issaquah.wednet.edu/family/supports.
Information about meal distribution, including a list of pick-up sites

div.div: Classified School Employees Week: Celebrating the People who Keep our Schools Running Smoothly

For the final day of Classified School Employees Week, meet the kitchen staff of Sunny Hills Elementary School: Donna Magnuson, Melanie Troutman, and Monica Pak. They recently played a big role in developing several scratch-made recipes that will be served at their school and other schools in the district. Like all of our district’s nutrition staff, they make sure students aren’t hungry so they can focus on learning.
Donna has worked at Sunny Hills for 21 years, Melanie has worked in the district for nine years, and Monica is in her first year. Donna and Melanie both attended Sunny Hills themselves when they were kids!
“We work as a team to solve problems and make the kitchen run easier,” Donna says. Thank you to all our classified staff! It takes a lot of time, work and dedication to keep our schools running, and it couldn’t happen without you. view more

img.alt: Classified School Employees Week: Celebrating the People who Keep our Schools Running Smoothly

div.div: Classified School Employees Week: Celebrating the People who Keep our Schools Running Smoothly

div.p: It’s Classified School Employees Week, and we’re recognizing a classified employee or group of employees each day. These are the people who do the work to keep our schools running so students can focus on learning.

Today, meet landscape technician Dani Tronsen, who works at Sunset Elementary, Cougar Ridge Elementary and Pine Lake Middle School. She studied horticulture in college and ran a landscaping business before joining the district about a year ago.

“It’s nice to use my knowledge and expertise to make people proud of where their kids go to school,” Dani says. “If we can keep the school looking nice people want to be a part of it. And a lot of our work isn’t just making it look nice, but it’s also about safety.”
Dani often interacts with students who are curious about her work and uses it as an opportunity to teach them about plants, storm water, insects and other important topics.
Thank you to all our classified staff! It takes a lot of time, work and dedication to keep our schools running, and it couldn’t happen without you.

img.alt: Classified School Employees Week: Celebrating the People who Keep our Schools Running Smoothly

div.span: The Issaquah School District complies with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations and does not discriminate on the basis of sex, race, creed, religion, color, national origin, age, honorably discharged veteran or military status, sexual orientation including gender expression or identity, the presence of any sensory, mental or physical disability, or the use of a trained dog guide or service animal by a person with a disability in its programs and activities, or employment related matters, and provides equal access to the Boy Scouts and other designated youth groups. The following employees are designated to handle questions and complaints of alleged discrimination: Assistant Superintendent of Human Resources, District Title IX Coordinator, Section 504/ADA Coordinator or Compliance Coordinator for 28A.540 and 28A.642 RCW, in writing or by telephone. The Issaquah School District will also take steps to assure that national origin persons who lack English language skills can participate in all educational programs, services and activities. For information regarding interpretation and translation services or transitional bilingual education programs, contact Kathy Connally
For general information or to be directed to a specific department, please contact the ISD Receptionist at 425-837-7000.
Lisa Hechtman, Civil Rights Compliance Officer
